poem: Title: Mistmorrow Mirk Beware the mizzly mistmorrow murk, Where shrouded shadows softly stir. In foggy fibres, fey folk lurk, A-whisperin' their mystic blur. The phantoms flit on filmy flight, As morning's muffled mumble moans. Their frothy fingers, flickering light, Ensnare the slumb'ring Shroomish groans. "Prepare thee well," the elders warn, "For vaporous vapors oft deceive. Anoint thine eyes with Tarnished Thorn, Lest fog-bound fears thy form bereave." With Silvered Sword and Salted Shield I venture forth to face the fray. Each snuffling snort and snicker sealed, To pierce the pall and part the gray. A-glistenin' in the gloaming glade, The Fogfin'd Fop with forked feet. On sodden soil its slime displayed, As I approach, my heart's beat fleet. "Unhand thy prey, thou foul fiend! For I shall not be brought to heel." My blade did sing as blows careened, And felled the Fogfin'd Fop I dealt. With bullyroar and halloing, Returned I, the hero hailed. In halls of men, the minstrels sing, Of the Shroomish saved and specter failed. And so the mizzly mistmorrow comes, Its terrors tamed by dauntless deeds. Yet ever in the fog-full hums, The shadow-shapes and phantom seeds.
